Award.AwardTitle: CRII: III: Using Genomic Context to Understand Evolutionary Histories of Individual Genes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Evolutionary trees show relationships between organisms through evolutionary time, and are central to many biomedical applications such as understanding protein function and analyzing the human microbiome. Interestingly, evolutionary histories can change across the genome, creating a complex genomic landscape. Understanding genome-wide evolution requires sophisticated computational tools that can analyze the rapidly growing set of genomes sequenced from species spanning the tree of life. Currently available methods for inferring these complex evolutionary histories have serious limitations, either in terms of accuracy or scalability to large datasets. This project will develop new computational methods for reconstructing evolutionary trees for individual segments of the genome while considering their connections to other parts of the genome. The computational methods developed will be made publicly available to the community of evolutionary biologists, and will help improve various downstream biomedical analyses. To facilitate adoption, the PI will train biologists interested in the new methods. Beyond impacting the research community, the PI will contribute to new promising diversity initiatives at UC San Diego to engage URM/Women undergraduate students in research projects defined in the exciting overlap between biology and computing.

A "gene tree" shows the evolutionary history for a small segment of the genome, and accurate reconstruction of each gene tree can be difficult because a small segment may provide little data and only a weak signal. A principled approach for improving gene tree estimation is to consider the connection between different parts of the genome. However, computational limitations of such co-estimation approaches have left researchers with only one feasible option: to infer gene trees independently for each segment, ignoring the underlying genome-wide patterns of evolution. This project will develop new scalable statistical methods for inferring gene trees given genomic sequence data and a genome-wide description of the evolutionary history, the so-called species tree. The focus will be on a specific probabilistic model of gene trees, the multi-species coalescent model, that links population level patterns of allele differentiation to species level histories. Scalable gene tree inference under this model remains a poorly studied problem. To develop scalable methods for calculating and optimizing likelihood scores with respect to the multi-species coalescent model, the project will use algorithmic techniques such as divide-and-conquer and dynamic programming. Other approaches that will be explored include designing simplified optimization scores that are easier to compute than the full likelihood and developing new approximations to the likelihood function. If successful, the project will produce pioneering scalable solutions for inferring gene trees given the species tree under the multi-species coalescent model, and such a method will have substantial positive impact on downstream biological analyses. Moreover, this project can pave the way for scalable solutions to an even more complex inference problem, where the goal is to co-estimate a large number of gene trees and the species tree in one analysis. For further information see the project web page: http://eceweb.ucsd.edu/~smirarab/2016/01/27/genetrees.html

POR.DRECONTENT:
Reconstructing the evolutionary history of the genome is a prerequisite to many downstream biological analyses. Building these histories, modeled as hierarchies called phylogenetic trees, requires advanced algorithms that model genome evolution carefully. The goal of this project was developing new algorithms for reconstructing evolutionary trees in parts of the genome based on the context provided by the rest of the genome.

The work performed as part of this award has led to

  • publication of 15 journal papers, an opinion piece, and two conference papers,
  • development of 9 open-source and publically available software tools (ASTRAL-III, ASTRAL-MP, INSTRAL, Dual-birth, TADA, DiscoVista, DISTIQUE, TreeShrink, and MVroot),
  • several simulated and empirical benchmarking dataset made publically available to other researchers,
  • several workshops and software schools held to train biologists in the use of the tools and methods mentioned above, and
  • training of a diverse set of graduate and undergraduate students in computer science and its applications to biology.

A complete list of these outcomes is given here: http://eceweb.ucsd.edu/~smirarab/2016/01/27/genetrees.html

The research performed here focused on several problems related to the intellectual merit of the project. Two papers (DOIs: 10.1186/s12864-018-4620-2 and 10.1093/molbev/msx261) focused on finding errors in genomic data before reconstructing their evolutionary history. Importantly, as proposed, error detection is done by looking at the distributions of evolutionary trees across the genome in a joint manner. A related work (10.1371/journal.pone.0182238) developed a method for reducing the error in finding the root (i.e., the origin) of a tree inferred from the data. We also developed a tool (10.1016/j.ympev.2018.01.019) for visualizing patterns of evolution across the genome. Five papers (10.1186/s12859-018-2129-y, 10.1093/bioinformatics/btz211, 10.1186/s12864-016-3098-z, 10.1016/j.ympev.2018.10.033, 10.1093/sysbio/syz045) developed methods for reconstructing the overall evolutionary history of species (the species tree) from the histories of individual genes in the genome (gene trees). A related paper (10.1109/TCBB.2017.2757930) analyzed the theoretical properties of one of these methods, answering the question: how many genes do we need to infer the species tree with high probability? Two other papers (10.1093/molbev/msw079 and 10.3390/genes9030132) developed statistical measures for estimating the confidence in evolutionary relationships reconstructed from data. Another theoretical paper looked at the human genome and developed a new model to infer the history of repeated elements across the human genome (10.1093/sysbio/syx088). Finally, two articles focused on downstream applications of the gene trees in microbiome analyses (10.1093/bioinformatics/btz394 and 10.1128/mSystems.00021-18).

 

Biologists have already adopted several tools developed here in their analysis pipelines. As examples, ASTRAL-III has been cited more than 70 times since 2018 and has emerged as a leading tool in species tree estimation. Our method on computing branch support has also been cited more than 170 times since 2016. Thus, beyond computer science, the outcomes of the project have made a significant broader impact on evolutionary biology. We believe our efforts on training users in the use of our software and on maintaining the tools has played a significant role in the successful adoption of the tools.

 

Finally, the project has helped to educate several undergraduate and graduate students. For undergraduates, the focus has been on exciting students from a computational background (including CS, ECE, and Math) on questions in biology. These students, from diverse gender and ethnic backgrounds, were given a chance to work on computational problems related to biology. The experience led them to learn about the field, publish papers (in two cases), and join a Ph.D. program in CS (one student), bioinformatics (one student) or in Math (one student). Several Ph.D. and MS students also had a chance to work on impactful computational problems as a result of this project. Two of the Ph.D. students have now graduated and have continued their career in computational biology (as a teaching assistant professor and a post-doctoral researcher). Several others are on their path to graduation and subsequently impactful careers in data science, either in academia or industry.
